moves.1. e4 e5 2. d4: I free up my queen and bishops in conjunction with the centre game...
moves.3... Nc6: Now my opponent develops a knight...
moves.4. Qe3: ...and I retreat my queen, in conjunction with the Paulsen attack.
moves.4... Nb4: The knight is eyeing up my king, queen and rook...
moves.5. Na3: ...so I cover the c2 square with mine.
moves.5... b6: My opponent opens up a pawn, possibly hoping to fianchetto the bishop...
moves.6... Bc5: ...but the other bishop comes out to attack the queen...
moves.7... Qxg5 8. Bxg5: ...and I get the swap I was hoping for.
moves.9. O-O-O: ...but I can't understand why I castled queenside...
moves.12. Nh3: ...and I put my other knight on the edge, keeping the e-file half-open, and the f3 square clear...
moves.12... Nxe4: ...as the knight takes the bait of my king's pawn...
moves.13. Re1: ...and is instantly pinned down by my rook...
moves.13... d5: ...and although the queen's pawn moves forward to cover any rook attack...
moves.14. f3: ...I push up my pawn to ensure a win of more for less...
moves.15... O-O-O 16. fxe4: ...but finally remove the knight, with a net gain...
moves.16... Rhe8: ...and my opponent lines up a two-pronged attack on my e4 pawn...
moves.17. Ba6+: ...but I move up my bishop to connect my rooks and check the king to create a distraction...
moves.17... Kb8 18. exd5: ...allowing me to win a pawn and open up and contest the e-file.
moves.18... Ne7: The knight retreats to cover the rook and attack my d5 pawn...
moves.19. Bc4: ...so I cover the pawn with my bishop...
moves.19... g5 20. Be5: ...and my other bishop moves into the centre to potentially fork the knight and a rook...
moves.20... Ng6: ...but the knight moves out of the way...
moves.21. Bf6: ...so I attack the d-rook and open up the e-file, and with both of my opponent's rooks now under attack...
moves.21... Rxe1+ 22. Rxe1: ...I get the exchange I was looking for.
moves.22... Rd6: Although my opponent lines up my bishop...
moves.23. Ba6: ...I push up its twin to line up a potential checkmate, blocking off the king's escape route...
moves.23... c5: ...but my opponent moves up the c-pawn to give him that escape route by c7...
moves.24. Re8+: ...so I attack on the top rank...
moves.25... Kd7 26. Rd8+: ...and again, on both occasions being helped by the bishops...
moves.28. Bb7: Now I move my bishop to help my d-pawn...
moves.31... Kd8: ...and as the king moves onto his starting rank...
moves.32. d6: ...I can push up my pawn even further, with the b-to e-files on the 7th rank being controlled by my bishops and pawn.
moves.32... Nxh3: Although the knight removes another pawn...
moves.33... Kc8: ...forcing him in front of my white-square bishop...
moves.34. Be8: ...which then moves to the top rank to shield my very passed pawn...
moves.34... Nf4 35. d7+: ...which can see that the way ahead is clear. Its next move would have been to d8, to become a queen, and then she would have helped my bishops to possibly clear the board but certainly trap the king.
